worms.model

Interface IFacade

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    Facade

    public interface IFacade
    Implement this interface to connect your code to the user interface.
    • For separating the code that you wrote from the code that was provided to you, put your code in the src folder. The code that is provided to you stays in the src-provided folder. If you modify the provided code, it's advised to move the modified code to the src folder as well, so that your changes are not accidentally overwritten by an update.
    • You should at least add the following classes to the package worms.model:
      • a class World for representing the world
      • a class Worm for representing a worm
      • a class Food for representing a food ration
      • a class Projectile for representing a projectile
      • a class Program for representing a program
      • a class Facade that implements this interface (IFacade).
    • The header of that Facade class should look as follows:
      class Facade implements IFacade { ... }
      Consult the Java tutorial for more information on interfaces, if necessary.
    • Each method defined in the interface IFacade must be implemented by the class Facade. For example, the implementation of getX should call a method of the given worm to retrieve its x-coordinate.
    • Methods in this interface are allowed to throw only ModelException. No other exception types are allowed. This exception can be thrown only if calling a method of your Worm class with the given parameters would violate a precondition or if the method of your Worm class throws an exception (if so, wrap the exception in a ModelException). ModelException should not be used anywhere outside of your Facade implementation.
    • The rules described above and the documentation described below for each method apply only to the class implementing IFacade. Your class for representing worms should follow the rules described in the assignment.
    • Do not modify the signatures of the methods defined in this interface. You can however add additional methods, as long as these additional methods do not overload the existing ones. Each additional method must be implemented in your class Facade.
    • Your Facade class should offer a default constructor.

    • Method Detail

      • addEmptyTeam

        void addEmptyTeam(World world,
                java.lang.String newName)
        Create and add an empty team with the given name to the given world. (For single-student groups that do not implement teams, this method should have no effect)

      • addNewFood

        void addNewFood(World world)
        Create and add a new food ration to the given world. The food must be placed at a random adjacent location. (For single-student groups that do not implement food, this method should have no effect)

      • addNewWorm

        void addNewWorm(World world,
              Program program)
        Create and add a new worm to the given world. The new worm must be placed at a random adjacent location. The new worm can have an arbitrary (but valid) radius and direction. The new worm may (but isn't required to) have joined a team. The worm must behave according to the provided program, or is controlled by the player if the given program is null.

      • canFall

        boolean canFall(Worm worm)
        Returns whether or not the given worm can fall down

      • canMove

        boolean canMove(Worm worm)
        Returns whether or not the given worm is allowed to move.

      • canTurn

        boolean canTurn(Worm worm,
              double angle)
        Returns whether or not the given worm can turn by the given angle.

      • createFood

        Food createFood(World world,
              double x,
              double y)
        Create a new food ration that is positioned at the given location in the given world.
        Parameters:
        world - The world in which to place the created food ration
        x - The x-coordinate of the position of the new food ration (in meter)
        y - The y-coordinate of the position of the new food ration (in meter) (For single-student groups that do not implement food, this method should have no effect)

      • createWorld

        World createWorld(double width,
                double height,
                boolean[][] passableMap,
                java.util.Random random)
        Creates a new world.
        Parameters:
        width - The width of the world (in meter)
        height - The height of the world (in meter)
        passableMap - A rectangular matrix indicating which parts of the terrain are passable and impassable. This matrix is derived from the transparency of the pixels in the image file of the terrain. passableMap[r][c] is true if the location at row r and column c is passable, and false if that location is impassable. The elements in the first row (row 0) represent the pixels at the top of the terrain (i.e., largest y-coordinates). The elements in the last row (row passableMap.length-1) represent pixels at the bottom of the terrain (smallest y-coordinates). The elements in the first column (column 0) represent the pixels at the left of the terrain (i.e., smallest x-coordinates). The elements in the last column (column passableMap[0].length-1) represent the pixels at the right of the terrain (i.e., largest x-coordinates).
        random - A random number generator, seeded with the value obtained from the command line or from GUIOptions, that can be used to randomize aspects of the world in a repeatable way.
        Returns:
        The world.

      • createWorm

        Worm createWorm(World world,
              double x,
              double y,
              double direction,
              double radius,
              java.lang.String name,
              Program program)
        Create a new worm that is positioned at the given location in the given world, looks in the given direction, has the given radius and the given name.
        Parameters:
        world - The world in which to place the created worm
        x - The x-coordinate of the position of the new worm (in meter)
        y - The y-coordinate of the position of the new worm (in meter)
        direction - The direction of the new worm (in radians)
        radius - The radius of the new worm (in meter)
        name - The name of the new worm
        program - The program that defines this worm's behavior, or null if this worm is controlled by the player

      • getJumpStep

        double[] getJumpStep(Projectile projectile,
                   double t)
        Returns the location on the jump trajectory of the given projectile after a time t.
        Returns:
        An array with two elements, with the first element being the x-coordinate and the second element the y-coordinate

      • getJumpStep

        double[] getJumpStep(Worm worm,
                   double t)
        Returns the location on the jump trajectory of the given worm after a time t.
        Returns:
        An array with two elements, with the first element being the x-coordinate and the second element the y-coordinate

      • getJumpTime

        double getJumpTime(Projectile projectile,
                 double timeStep)
        Determine the time that the given projectile can jump until it hits the terrain, hits a worm, or leaves the world. The time should be determined using the given elementary time interval.
        Parameters:
        projectile - The projectile for which to calculate the jump time.
        timeStep - An elementary time interval during which you may assume that the projectile will not completely move through a piece of impassable terrain.
        Returns:
        The time duration of the projectile's jump.

      • getJumpTime

        double getJumpTime(Worm worm,
                 double timeStep)
        Determine the time that the given worm can jump until it hits the terrain or leaves the world. The time should be determined using the given elementary time interval.
        Parameters:
        worm - The worm for which to calculate the jump time.
        timeStep - An elementary time interval during which you may assume that the worm will not completely move through a piece of impassable terrain.
        Returns:
        The time duration of the worm's jump.

      • getWinner

        java.lang.String getWinner(World world)
        Returns the name of a single worm if that worm is the winner, or the name of a team if that team is the winner. This method should null if there is no winner. (For single-student groups that do not implement teams, this method should always return the name of the winning worm, or null if there is no winner)

      • isActive

        boolean isActive(Food food)
        Returns whether or not the given food ration is alive (active), i.e., not eaten. (For single-student groups that do not implement food, this method should always return false)

      • isActive

        boolean isActive(Projectile projectile)
        Returns whether the given projectile is still alive (active).

      • isAdjacent

        boolean isAdjacent(World world,
                 double x,
                 double y,
                 double radius)
        Checks whether the given circular region of the given world, defined by the given center coordinates and radius, is passable and adjacent to impassable terrain.
        Parameters:
        world - The world in which to check adjacency
        x - The x-coordinate of the center of the circle to check
        y - The y-coordinate of the center of the circle to check
        radius - The radius of the circle to check
        Returns:
        True if the given region is passable and adjacent to impassable terrain, false otherwise.

      • isAlive

        boolean isAlive(Worm worm)
        Returns whether the given worm is alive

      • isGameFinished

        boolean isGameFinished(World world)
        Returns whether the game in the given world has finished.

      • isImpassable

        boolean isImpassable(World world,
                   double x,
                   double y,
                   double radius)
        Checks whether the given circular region of the given world, defined by the given center coordinates and radius, is impassable.
        Parameters:
        world - The world in which to check impassability
        x - The x-coordinate of the center of the circle to check
        y - The y-coordinate of the center of the circle to check
        radius - The radius of the circle to check
        Returns:
        True if the given region is impassable, false otherwise.

      • jump

        void jump(Projectile projectile,
        double timeStep)
        Make the given projectile jump to its new location. The new location should be determined using the given elementary time interval.
        Parameters:
        projectile - The projectile that needs to jump
        timeStep - An elementary time interval during which you may assume that the projectile will not completely move through a piece of impassable terrain.

      • jump

        void jump(Worm worm,
        double timeStep)
        Make the given worm jump to its new location. The new location should be determined using the given elementary time interval.
        Parameters:
        worm - The worm that needs to jump
        timeStep - An elementary time interval during which you may assume that the worm will not completely move through a piece of impassable terrain.

      • parseProgram

        ParseOutcome<?> parseProgram(java.lang.String programText,
                           IActionHandler handler)
        Try to parse the given program. You can use an instance of the worms.model.programs.ProgramParser. When the program is executed, the execution of an action statement must call the corresponding method of the given action handler. This executes the action as if a human player has initiated it, and will eventually call the corresponding method on the facade.
        Parameters:
        programText - The program text to parse
        handler - The action handler on which to execute commands
        Returns:
        the outcome of parsing the program, which can be a success or a failure. You can create a ParseOutcome object by means of its two static methods, success and failure.

      • hasProgram

        boolean hasProgram(Worm worm)
        Returns whether or not the given worm is controlled by a program.
        Returns:
        true if the given worm is controlled by a program, false otherwise

      • isWellFormed

        boolean isWellFormed(Program program)
        Returns whether or not the given program is well-formed. A program is well-formed if a for-each statement does not (directly or indirectly) contain one or more action statements.
        Parameters:
        program - The program to check
        Returns:
        true if the program is well-formed; false otherwise
